name: q14_3
probTex: Show all solutions of $e^z=3z^2$ with $|z|<1$ are also solutions of $z=\overline z$.
solnTex:
We will use Rouche's theorem, which states that if $|f|<|g|$ on $\partial\Omega$ then $g$ and $f+g$ have the same number of roots in $\Omega$. First look at the function $e^z-3z^2=e^z+(-3z^2)$, we want the roots of this function. If $|z|=1$, then $|-3z^2|=3$. Also,
\[|e^z|=|e^{x+iy}|=|e^x|=e^x\]
and 
\[ rac{1}{e}\leq e^x\leq e\]
for $-1\leq x\leq1$. Additionally, $e<3$ so in particular $|e^z|\leq e<3=|-3z^2|$. Now we know how many roots $-3z^2$ has in the unit disc, it has 2 (we have to count multiplicity). That means $e^z-3z^2$ has 2 roots in the unit disc. However, $e^z-3z^2$ has 2 roots on the real interval $(-1,1)$, we can prove this with the intermediate value theorem. If $h(x)=e^x-3x^2$ then 
\[h(-1)= rac{1}{e}-3<0\] 
\[h(0)=1>0\]
\[h(1)=e-3<0.\]
Thus $h$ has a (real) root between $-1$ and $0$ and another root between $0$ and $1$. These are the only roots of $e^z-3z^2$, as we already saw, by Rouche's theorem. The fact that they are real means they are solutions to $z=\overline z$, as required.
